citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
At the time of inspection the following animals were identified as needing veterinary care:
-One turkey hen had significant feather loss on her lower back.
- In pen 12, there were two adult black and white hens (Light Braham), and one multi-colored hen (Mile Fleur) with
significant feather loss on their backs.
- In pen 13, there was one adult brown and cream hen with significant feather loss on her back and neck.
- In pen 17, there was one adult multi-colored hen with significant feather loss on her back.
Lack of daily observations and communication with the attending veterinarian can result in worsening of the conditions.
Feather loos can be caused by many factors including: an aggressive rooster, overbreeding, molting, mites, parasites,
bacterial or fungal infections, poor nutrition, stress, boredom, bullying, and feather pulling. Birds that appear sick can be
due to a variety of health conditions that require consultation with the attending veterinarian for accurate diagnosis and
treatment.
The licensee must complete daily observations to assess the health and well-being of animals and frequent
communication with the attending veterinarian to allow for timely and accurate information to be conveyed to the attending
veterinarian on problems of animal health, behavior, and well-being. In addition, the facility must follow the attending
veterinarians recommendations to record daily observations for the birds, separate birds that are sick, injured or being
picked on, and to add saddles or aprons on birds with feather loss.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
